## Welcome {-}

This self-assessment questionnaire is designed to help you evaluate your readiness for the **Transport Data Science** (TRAN5340M) module at the University of Leeds. The module focuses on applying data science techniques to solve real-world transport problems using open source software, with a strong emphasis on reproducible workflows.

Please answer each question honestly to get an accurate assessment of your prior knowledge and skills.

## Self-Assessment Scoring

After completing the questionnaire, use the following scoring guide to assess your readiness:

### Scoring Instructions
For each question, assign points based on your answer:

- **Very comfortable/Extensive/Advanced**: 4 points
- **Comfortable/Intermediate**: 3 points  
- **Somewhat comfortable/Basic**: 2 points
- **Not very comfortable/Beginner**: 1 point
- **No experience/Not familiar**: 0 points

### Score Interpretation

**0-20 points: Beginner Level**
- Limited programming and data science experience
- May find the module challenging without significant preparation
- Should consider completing introductory courses before starting

**21-40 points: Intermediate Level**
- Basic programming and data analysis skills
- Familiar with some key concepts
- Will benefit from reviewing prerequisite materials
- Should be able to follow the module with dedicated effort

**41-60 points: Advanced Level**
- Strong programming and data science skills
- Familiar with many transport-related concepts
- Well-prepared for the module
- May be able to contribute to discussions and help peers

**61-80 points: Expert Level**
- Extensive experience with R/Python and data science
- Deep knowledge of transport planning concepts
- Likely to find the module content familiar but challenging
- Well-prepared to tackle advanced topics

## Recommended Preparation

Based on your self-assessment, here are some recommended resources to prepare for the module:

### For Beginners (0-20 points)

**Warning: you are advised to NOT take this module unless you invest a substantial amount of time (at least 10 hours, e.g. 2 hours per week in the runup to the course) completing preparatory work.**

1. **R Programming**: Complete the [RStudio Primers](https://rstudio.cloud/learn/primers) (first 4 sessions) or [DataCamp's Free Introduction to R](https://www.datacamp.com/courses/free-introduction-to-r)
2. **Python**: Complete [Python for Data Science](https://www.datacamp.com/courses/intro-to-python-for-data-science) on DataCamp
3. **Git/GitHub**: Learn the basics from [GitHub's Git Guide](https://guides.github.com/introduction/git-handbook/)
4. **Command Line**: Complete [The Linux Command Line](https://ryanstutorials.net/linuxtutorial/) (for Windows users, focus on PowerShell basics)

### For Intermediate Learners (21-40 points)

**Note: you are advised to invest additional time (at least 5 hours) completing preparatory work to ensure you can keep up with the module content.**

1. **Data Analysis**: 
   - **R/Tidyverse**: Work through [R for Data Science](https://r4ds.had.co.nz/) chapters 1-5
   - **Python**: Work through [Python for Data Analysis](https://wesmckinney.com/book/) chapters 1-5 or [Pandas documentation](https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/user_guide/index.html)
2. **Spatial Data**: 
   - **R**: Read [Geocomputation with R](https://r.geocompx.org/) chapters 2-4
   - **Python**: Read [Geocomputation with Python](https://py.geocompx.org/) chapters 2-4
3. **Transport Concepts**: 
   - **R**: Explore the [Transport chapter of Geocomputation with R](https://r.geocompx.org/transport.html)
   - **Python**: Explore the [Transport chapter of Geocomputation with Python](https://py.geocompx.org/transport.html)
4. **Version Control**: Complete [GitHub's Learning Lab](https://lab.github.com/)

### For Advanced Learners (41-80 points)

**Great! You are well-prepared for the module but may benefit from reviewing some advanced topics.**

1. **Transport Data Science**: 
   - **R**: Review [Reproducible Road Safety Research with R](https://itsleeds.github.io/rrsrr/)
   - **Python**: Explore [PySTATS19](https://github.com/Mayazure/py-stats19) and Python-based road safety analysis
2. **Open Data Sources**: Explore [OpenStreetMap](https://www.openstreetmap.org/) and [Stats19](https://data.gov.uk/dataset/cb7ae6f0-4be6-4935-9277-47e5ce24a11f/road-safety-data)
3. **Advanced Topics**: 
   - **R**: Read [Advanced R](https://adv-r.hadley.nz/) for deeper R knowledge
   - **Python**: Read [Effective Python](https://effectivepython.com/) or explore advanced Python data science libraries
